targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Connection Memory (KB)','Optimizer Memory (KB)','SQL Cache Memory (KB)')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**Page Reads/sec**:   *You want < 90*   
Number of physical database page reads issued per second. Normal OLTP workloads support 80 – 90 per second, but higher values may be a yellow flag for poor indexing or insufficient memory.

**Page Writes/sec**:   *You want < 90*   
Number of database pages physically written to disk per second. Normal OLTP workloads support 80 – 90 per second. Values over 90 should be crossed checked with “lazy writer/sec” and “checkpoint” counters. If the other counters are also high, then it may indicate insufficient memory

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page reads/sec','Page writes/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Page reads/sec vs Page writes/sec

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Bytes Written/sec] = AVG([bytes_written_per_second])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_file_stats]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[Bytes Read/sec] = AVG([bytes_read_per_second])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_file_stats]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**Readahead/sec**: 
Number of data pages read per second in anticipation of their use

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Readahead pages/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Readahead pages/sec

panels.description:
**Lazy Writes/Sec**: *You want< 20*   
Monitors the number of times per second that the Lazy Writer process moves dirty pages from the buffer to disk as it frees up buffer space. Lower is better with zero being ideal. When greater than 20, this counter indicates a need for more memory.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Lazy writes/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Lazy writes/sec

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,[value] = AVG([physical_memory_in_use_kb])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_process_memory]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**Readahead Rate**: *You want < 20%*   
The ratio of *Readahead/sec* and *Page Reads/ sec*. 
Number of data pages read per second in anticipation of their use. If this value is makes up even a sizeable minority of total Page Reads/sec (say, greater than 20% of total page reads), you may have too many physical reads occurring.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Readahead pages/sec','Page reads/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Readahead rate

panels.description:
**Checkpoint Pages/ sec**:   
Monitors the number of dirty pages, per second, that are flushed to disk when SQL Server invokes the checkpoint process. Checkpoint frequency is influenced by the recovery interval setting in sp_configure. High values for this counter may indicate insufficient memory or that the recovery interval is too high.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Checkpoint pages/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Checkpoint pages/sec

panels.description:
**Memory Grants Outstanding:**
Total number of processes per second that have successfully acquired a workspace memory grant.

**Memory Grants Pending**:
Total number of processes per second waiting for a workspace memory grant. Numbers higher than 0 indicate a lack of memory.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Memory Grants Outstanding','Memory Grants Pending')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Memory Grants

panels.description: **Page Lookups/sec**: The number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page Lookups/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Page Lookups/sec

panels.description:
**Log Flushes/sec**:   
Technically, the number of log pages flushed to the transaction log per second.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Log Flushes/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Log Flushes/sec

panels.description:
**Page lookups Rate**: *You want < 100*   
The ratio of *Page lookups/ sec* and *Batch Requests/ sec*. The number of requests to find a page in the buffer pool. When the ratio of batch requests to page lookups crests 100, you may have inefficient execution plans or too many adhoc queries.

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page Lookups/sec','Batch Requests/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Page Lookup Rate

panels.description:
**Free List Stalls/sec**:   *You want < 2*   
Monitors the number of requests per second where data requests stall because no buffers are available. Any value above 2 means SQL Server needs more memory

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Free list stalls/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Free list stalls/sec

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [clerk_name]
      ,[value] = sum([allocated_kb])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_memory_clerks]
  WHERE 1 = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [clerk_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.description:
**Page Life Expectancy**: *You want > 300*   
Tells, on average, how many seconds SQL Server expects a data page to stay in cache. The target on an OLTP system should be at least 300 (5 min). When under 300, this may indicate poor index design (leading to increased disk I/O and less effective use of memory) or, simply, a potential shortage of memory.

**IMPORTANT**
[https://www.sqlskills.com/blogs/paul/page-life-expectancy-isnt-what-you-think/](https://www.sqlskills.com/blogs/paul/page-life-expectancy-isnt-what-you-think/)

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Page Lookups/sec','Batch Requests/sec')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Page Life Expectancy

panels.description:
**Buffer cache hit ratio**:   *You want 100%*   
Long a stalwart counter used by SQL Server DBAs, this counter is no longer very useful. It monitors the percentage of data requests answer from the buffer cache since the last reboot. However, other counters are much better for showing current memory pressure that this one because it blows the curve. For example, PLE (page life expectancy) might suddenly drop from 2000 to 70, while buffer cache hit ration moves only from 98.2 to 98.1. Only be concerned by this counter if it’s value is regularly below 90 (for OLTP) or 80 (for very large OLAP).

targets.rawSql:
SELECT 
      [time] = $__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
      ,metric = [counter_name]
      ,[value] = AVG([cntr_value_calculated])
  FROM [dbo].[vw_sqlwatch_report_fact_perf_os_performance_counters]
  WHERE [aggregation_interval_minutes] = 1
  AND $__timeFilter(report_time)
  AND counter_name IN ('Buffer cache hit ratio')
  AND [sql_instance] = '$sql_instance'
  GROUP BY [counter_name]
      ,$__timeGroup([report_time], $aggregation) 
ORDER BY
  time ASC

panels.title: Buffer cache hit ratio
